Award.AwardTitle: Research Data: Activities of the U.S. National Committee for CODATA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The mission of the United States National Committee on Data for Science and Technology (U.S. CODATA) is to improve the stewardship, policy, and use of digital data and information for science and the broader society. U.S. CODATA engages in planning, program development, and administrative oversight of projects launched under its auspices, and is responsible for a program of activities at the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine related to research data and information. This proposal supports U.S. CODATA activities and one major CODATA meeting.

The digital revolution has created new opportunities in the management and use of all types of research and other data and information. Most areas of scientific research are currently data-driven and this has produced a broad range of quantitative and qualitative improvements in the research enterprise and in the communication of research results. While the technical systems in the digitally networked environment are progressing rapidly, they have also been a disruptive force in traditional way of scientific communication and impact evaluation. New models of scholarly exchange and knowledge production are quickly emerging, but they sufficiently established or understood, and their adoption depends on many social and scientific factors. Old endemic problems such as quality assurance, metadata and citation protocols, long-term digital preservation, reputation and reward systems, scientific integrity, and assessment methodologies for research data and information activities need to be addressed, especially in light of new digital knowledge technologies and applications. U.S. CODATA acts through the National Academy of Sciences, the adhering body to the International Council for Science and its CODATA commission, representing the U.S. data community and coordinating with CODATA's international activities. It will enable US participation in the international CODATA and conduct a meeting of U.S. CODATA to identify an agenda of activities within its mission to advance data management challenges in the United States; serve as a neutral convener to encourage and facilitate collaboration across disciplines and sectors on common interests in research data and information activities; and monitor and contribute to the development of U.S. government and research community positions on these issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CODATA, the Committee on Data for Science and Technology, is an interdisciplinary Scientific Committee of the International Science Council (ISC) that involves 22 national members plus others, such as international scientific unions, in issues of data science and data policy. Among the issues considered are data management problems, improvements in quality and accessibility of data, methods of data acquisition, and data accessibility. The National Academy of Sciences (NAS) represents the United States to CODATA through the U.S. National Committee for CODATA (U.S. CODATA). This allows for strong U.S. participation at both scientific and governance levels. This project allowed payment of dues for 2017 and communications with CODATA, which then provide opportunities for professional participation of U.S. scientists.

Intellectual Merit

The activities of the U.S. CODATA are centered on maintaining and developing partnerships and facilitating interactions across the Federal government, academic, and non-profit arenas. The U.S. CODATA/Board on Research Data and Information (BRDI) organized a board meeting in May 2018 at the NAS to discuss progress in current and future activities with the participation of CODATA U.S. leaders, members of the Board, and representatives from several government agencies.

The U.S. CODATA co-organized and hosted “Implementing FAIR Data for People and Machines: Impact and Implications,” a workshop held on September 11, 2019 at the NAS in Washington, DC. Ninety professionals from 67 organizations participated in the event and had the opportunity to discuss the latest approaches in the wide implementation of FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable) data in the U.S. and abroad, including case studies, federal perspectives, definition and measurement of FAIR, scholarly communication, and scientific workflows. Presentations from the event are freely available and an open-access journal article describing the event will be published in 2020.

At the 2018 CODATA General Assembly in Gaborone, Botswana, the U.S. CODATA proposed a resolution on increased representativity at the Executive Committee level, which passed. U.S. participation in CODATA is demonstrated by the leadership exercised by the current CODATA secretary general, a U.S. data professional, and the work of U.S. scientists who lead five of the International Task Groups.

BRDI organizes other separately funded activities, such as the Roundtable on Aligning Incentives for Open Science and a consensus study on Realizing Opportunities for Advanced and Automated Workflows in Scientific Research, which also inform the activities of U.S. CODATA.

Broader Impact

“Implementing FAIR Data for People and Machines: Impact and Implications,” was co-organized by U.S. CODATA/BRDI in collaboration with CENDI, NFAIS, and RDA. In the process of organizing this event, the co-organizers shared their knowledge to construct an agenda with talks and panels of great interest to the audience (Federal agencies, academia, and non-profit participants). This opportunity allowed interactions and exchange of ideas among speakers and participants. U.S. CODATA/BRDI also hosted a group of U.S. and international data scientists at the NAS that discussed FAIR data and services.

U.S. leadership in CODATA results in an ever-increasing vigorous set of activities and approaches, which benefit U.S. science by offering more opportunities for the involvement of U.S. data scientists and professionals.

U.S. CODATA convening activities highlight U.S. advances on data science and management within an international context, and foster the involvement of a variety of U.S. stakeholders in technical activities and in the discussion of the latest developments in data science, a quickly developing field of study that underlies all other science disciplines.
